Imagine: a probability waveform resembling one that exists around a subatomic particle, but this one is gigantic sized and encompasses every possible path in every possible timeline. The waveform (in whatever medium it exists) has your consciousness and every event that occurs moving through it forward in time. Your decisions (or the random actions that occur to every particle during every moment in time,) affect where your consciousness moves in your localized area of the traveling waveform. The changes in your waveform's path can affect the people and objects who also exist in your vicinity. Thus, you exist in a single universe - multiple universes with infinite versions of you are not generated. All that changes with every decision, and every interaction between every particle, is the shape of the traveling waveform. The waveform itself can only predict the probability that you'll do any one thing- some things are more liable to happen than others. There are no other worlds where other versions of you are doing other things. Because the waveform path that could have led to those events collapsed as you and the universe moved forward in time to a "present" that didn't include those things.

So what collapses the waveform to create the present? I'll call it the Collapsing Force. It would have to be something that was universe-wide and aware of the position of every particle and bit of energy in all of existence so it could observe them and collapse the Universal Waveform. But now we're getting into metaphysical territory here. Anyway, if I were creating a fictional universe and wanted to have people create alternate versions of their worlds, this would be the system I would create - a machine that could alter the universal waveform, which in turn alters the nature of the "present". I wouldn't have thousands of Worfs popping out of portals or people making entire armies out of their alternative reality clones or some crazy shit like that.

Isn't it a bit strong to say that there is zero supporting evidence?

I think more in such terms that the evidence we got so far, including as seen in the experiments you mentioned, fit the many words interpretation. So evidence-wise it more feels like we are where we were with general relativty some decades back. Lots of supporting evidence, but not conclusive yet.

Take the delayed choice variant of the double slit experiment. Where you shine a light on two slits, and the shadow on the wall behind shows an interference pattern. But when you put up some observation method, either before or after the slits, the shadow on the wall in front of your eyes changes from an interference pattern to just two shadows.

When I previously had the copenhagen interpretation as my working models, this experiment and lots of others were totally mind-boggling and made no sense. You had to do a lot of intellectual gymnastics and time travel to square things. But in many worlds it is exactly what you would expect to see, observing you split the branch and only see one outcome. Not observing all the fungible universes' probability wave interferes with itself and creates the pattern on the wall.

And there are many more like this. Anyway, just wanted to point that out. It's not like many worlds is just a "crazy idea" out of many. It is more that there is one, and only one, that is really matches all the evidence so far. And it also makes testable predictions. Heck quantum logic gates for example, we're even building commercial computers based on the testable and proven predictions made by the many worlds interpretation.

After all, the many worlds interpretation is just assuming that the math in quantum mechanics is true.

What I find a little puzzling is that the many worlds theory (or at least one version of it) is supposed to explain why it should be that the physical properties of our universe are ideal for the formation of galaxies, planets and eventually life. We 'get around' this by saying that there is an 'infinite' (or more logically just extremely large) number of other universes, where the physics is minutely different to ours, so ours isn't special, there eventually had to be one like ours. But if the physical properties of all the 'other universes' are minutely different to ours, then they can not form galaxies etc or do anything much else. They don't work - they would collapse almost as soon as they came into existence, or never come into existence at all. So we still end up with one universe, and we haven't really explained anything... Which is kind of funny as well as mind-bending, of course.

I think I got it. Here's the mathematical proof for the Many worlds theorem.
Let's start with the cross product of vectors. If we regard the x-axis as front and back, the y axis as left and right, then the direction of the cross product of two arbitrary vectors in 2D is either up or down. But in 3D they have infinite possibilities. So we can say that 3D is actually a combination of all possible 2D planes. (you turn the vectors) You can also do that using a cone or any other prism.
Since 2D is also a combination of all possible 1D lines, and 1D lines are a combination of all possible points(see circle equation x^2+y^2=r^2- it contains all points with distance r from center, and it becomes a circle- a 1D curve!) we can extend it by saying that 4D is all possible 3D spaces.
Wait, isn't the Many worlds theory just about that? all scenarios on play together!

Misleading straw-man nonsense. The many-worlds interpretation is NOT complex. It is incredibly simple. It is the most simple interpretation of quantum mechanics that exists, because it avoids all of the problems of the wave-function collapse. The fact that it involves an infinite number of universes is not an indication of complexity. Complexity comes about by the number of ad hoc hypotheses and assumptions needed, and the MWI relies on very few assumptions. So the many-worlds interpretation is the most reasonable interpretation.

Maybe stick to educating people instead of subtly adding in your own uninformed opinions.

This is misleading. It's like a ripple. You can trace every path between where the ripple started and where you're looking to work out the height of the water at that point, but you wouldn't say that the ripple is branching repeatedly. Also, we know that all "branches" exist in a small scale because they interfere when you get the same universe twice (two waves passing through the same point). On a large scale, you can't get exactly the same universe, so we haven't tested it.

We don't observe cats that are both alive and dead at the same time.  Why not? 3) Will anything exist "after" the universe.  Really, it is the same problem.  Logically, the end of the universe should resemble the beginning but with a big crunch instead of a big bang.*cont*

Logically you could appeal to causality: you were born, you grew up and you died and obviously you were born before you died. "Why should it be different?"

This is the zen question "When a tree falls in a forest and nobody is around, does it make a sound?"  We assume that it does but how do we know?  To assume that things are different when we are not around would be placing too much importance on our own existence: the universe (presumably) exists whether we are there to observe it or not.  Besides, we can always set up a camera and a microphone and record the sound of a tree falling when we aren't there. :)

"what decides in which states it ends up being"

It does not end up in any one state.  Instead, we end up in two different states and in one state we see the particle in one state and in the other state we see the particle in another state.  The video was a bit misleading: this is not something that happens everywhere in the universe at the same time.

It doesn't.  It goes through all paths.  That's the point.  The problem is that our minds are limited to seeing only one path.  We are not able to perceive the universe being in multiple states at the same time.

"we could call that your god"

Actually, no.  Close your eyes and cover your ears.  Imagine that there is nothing that exists except you.  Now open your eyes and look around.  You couldn't see or hear the world around you.  Was it still there?  When you open your eyes every morning after sleeping, is that a religious experience for you?  The only basic assumption we are making is that the world exists even when we are not looking at it.  That doesn't make science a religion.

"particles seem to come in and out of existence randomly"

That is called "vacuum fluctuations".  The idea is based on the Heisenberg Uncertainty Principle applied to energy and time plus the equivalence of matter and energy.  The idea is that for short periods of time you can have a large amount of energy, large enough to create particle-antiparticle pairs.  These particles are charged so you expect to be able to detect them if you apply an external electric field.  We do but we can't see them.

"I find it far more likely..."

This is not a religion where you can form your own sect an believe what you want to believe.  This is science where you perform experiments and then decide what is likely based on the results.  With carefully designed experiments we expect to converge on the truth so that there is no need to argue philosophically.  We know that particles exist in more than one state at once because we observe particles acting as waves and classical theories do not explain this.

"I have a problem with people claiming this as a fact, without providing evidence for it."

I know what you mean but it is not something scientists just made up.  Consider the two slit experiment: do you realize that the pattern only collapses when we determine which slit the electrons pass through?  We can even have a detector detect elections passing through the slits but if we erase the data then we still see the pattern.  The many worlds interpretation explains this like no other theory.

I learned, from a YouTube video no less, that the Schrodinger's Cat experiment isn't about the cat being both alive and dead, but an illustration of quantum entanglement. In the experiment, some lethal device in the cat's box is triggered by the decay of a particle (a quantum object). When we're sitting outside the box /the particle/ is both decayed and not decayed, because we're not a part of the system. But the cat is, and has a very real way of telling if the particle decayed (death) or not.

This, again, misses the fundamental point of the Many Worlds interpretation: everyone that existed before the "branch point" exists in both/all "worlds" that result from that branch. Under Many Worlds, when a scientist measure a particle's spin, two versions of him/her result: one version that sees the spin as up, and one that sees it as down. Similarly, there will be two version of every person who learns of the result - one version that hears that it was up and one that hears it was down.

With the Many Worlds interpretation, the reason everyone  appears to see the same thing is because the states result from one outcome cannot meaningfully interact with the states that observed a different outcome. This, by the way, has the nice feature of restoring locality to Quantum Mechanics: each scientist making a measurement will see all possible outcomes, but, when interacting with the other scientists, each version can interact only with the version of the others that saw the same data.

The entire point of the Many Worlds interpretation is that wave functions do not collapse; rather when a single state interacts with something in a superposition, the single state fractures into a similar superposition. That means that when I measure the spin of a particle, I split into a superposition of seeing the particle as spin up and seeing it as spin down; neither state, however, is aware of the other(s), which is why the experiment seems to have only one outcome.

Grammar isn't the only tool for interpreting a statement - context is important as well. In any case, I don't care whether you understood my point, only whether you understand it now.

I'm sorry I wasn't clear.  In quantum mechanics we will have situations where a wave function may collapse and we will have a 50% chance of being in one quantum state and a 50% chance of being in another quantum state.  But when we look around we're not just looking at one thing: we are looking at everything.  To say the "most probable outcome occurs" is essentially a way of saying that we don't see things appear to happen at random at the macroscopic level.

In general, there is not outcome A or B but an infinite number.  Let's say for example we fire an electron at a wall in which case we don't have states A or B but a random location on the wall.  Thing is, if you only shoot one electron then you expect it to follow a straight line path, which is the most probable outcome.  Things get complicated when you shoot more than one electron at a wall because the wave functions interfere so the probability of an electron being in a certain place changes.

One perosn asked me about the problem of entropy in a deterministic universe.  She said "How can the universe be deterministic if entropy increases? The many worlds interpretation actually solves this problem because the cat, for example, is alive in one world and dead in another so you have no new information.  When an idea explains this much we tend to believe it to be true.

It may be hard for you to accept but the cat is neither alive nor dead before we open the box and it is neither alive nor dead after we open the box but (as is clear from the comments below) we can't get our heads around that idea so we collectively "decide" whether the cat is alive or not.  The cat goes on being neither alive nor dead and we explain the contradiction by saying that in one world the cat is alive and in another the cat is dead.  Many worlds is an "interpretation" of quantum mech.

Suppose our perception of time were slowing down.  If we go back to the beginning of time then we have the inflationary universe that expands at a rate faster than the speed of light.  As we approach the end of the universe our perception of time may slow down such that we perceive the universe as having no end and expanding forever. Hawking argues that a similar thing happens when you approach the event horizon of a black hole: gravity slows down time so that you never will experience the event

The universe supposedly started with a singularity: at this point there was zero entropy.  We can't have negative entropy and entropy is always increasing so the big bang, Hawking argued, had to be the beginning of time.  Hawking argued that perhaps the universe truly has no beginning or end but just is and it is only our perception of time that causes us to see a time-changing universe. The increasing expansion of the universe is a problem with this scenario but Hawking had an argument for that

This gets back to Hawking's argument about the human brain being a biological machine: machines obey the 2nd law of thermodynamics so that as we think the entropy of the universe increases.  But what if we have cause and effect backwards here?  What if the 2nd law of thermodynamics is an artifact of our brains' need to record events physically?  What is really cool is that then the big bang itself would be a result of our own perception: when we look back in time we see decreasing entropy.

Suppose though the aliens are just like us and they see the universe the way we do.  When we look at distant galaxies we see stars that existed billions of years ago.  If aliens in distant galaxies also look at these same galaxies then from non-locality we should expect teh aliens in distant galaxies to see the exact same things we do.  This means that non-locality could then be applied to events that took place before mankind even existed.

There's a bigger problem.  If an alien race exists do they see the same universe that we do at all?  If our perception of the universe is due to our brain's limitations then perhaps an alien race sees something completely different.  Perhaps an alien race could see the universe as a superposition of an infinite number of parallel universes, which is what the many worlds interpretation says the universe actually is.  This would make the alien's observation of ourselves irrelevant.

Does a tree fall in a forest if nobody is around?   Yes and no.  We have to assume that whenever there are two possibilities and we haven't made an observation then both possibilities actually happen.

So what happens if mankind is observed by an alien race that has brains like ours?  Presumably all of human history is arbitrary from their point of view: presumably we don't even exist until we are observed by the alien race.  How is this consistent with our view that we actually exist?

As there is no way for scientists to know who was the "first" one to make their measurement we can conclude that they BOTH were.  We can conclude in any situation where there is ambiguity as to what happened then BOTH things happened.  Does a tree fall in a forest if nobody is around?

Non-locality has experimentally been shown to occur.  So what is happening here?  There are three possibilities: 1) faster-than-light communication, 2) a message going back in time and then forward and 3) a deterministic universe.  Note that a deterministic universe is usually associated with hidden variables but recent experiments have shown that wave functions are real.  It turns out that possibilities 2) and 3) are not incompatible: you can have both scientists do experiments at the same time

Ah! Having read a little further, I see that we are using different terminology. In classical metaphysics the unobserved wave which you term "both B and C at the same time" would be termed "a potentiality." That is, it is not actually B and C at the same time, strictly speaking, it is *potentially* B or C. Rather like water is can be either steam or ice but cannot be said to be those things simultaneously.  This difference being that a wave always becomes either B or C as soon as it is observed.

This is precisely the point. A=A excludes the possibility of A=B or A=C if by B or C we mean something which is other than A. The reason why I question this way of talking about these things is because without the principle of non-contradiction (ie A=A) no science, mathematics, philosophy etc is possible. Things can be indeterminate, that is they can be potentially one thing or another. But to say that something IS both, mutually exclusive things at the same time is absurd.

History converges even more than it splits, as evidence degrades.

This is the difference between classical and quantum uncertainty.  In classical uncertainty the system is in some definite state, we just don't know what it is.  In quantum uncertainty the system is in a mixture of all possible states (what physicists call superposition).  We can't use classical uncertainty in a quantum system because our predictions will be wrong.  The classic example is the two slit experiment.  Wikipedia has a good article.  Search for "two slit experiment."

Schrodinger's Cat was designed by Shrodinger to illustrate how ridiculous the Copenhagen Interpretation was (to him). He did it by illustrating how, as a consequence of quantum mechanics, this cat in a box would be both alive and dead until observed. However, just like the term "Big Bang", it came to be used to _support_ the theory, rather than point out its flaws. (The term "Big Bang" was originally used to point out how wrong it was to imagine the beginning of the universe as an explosion).

A. There is no "Original Universe" - each universe has equal claim of being the "correct" universe.

B. The person will not succeed in destroying any universe because the Many Worlds interpretation says only that all possible outcomes occur, not that all outcomes are possible. Nothing suggests that destroying the universe is possible and nothing suggests that influencing other universes to a significant degree is possible.

How does Bell's inequality conflict with the Many Worlds interpretation? Bell's inequality simply shows that individual quantum events have multiple possible outcomes - that no set of "undiscovered variables" can fully replicate the observed behavior of quantum mechanical phenomena. The Many Worlds interpretation supposes that all of these possible outcomes of a particular quantum event actually occur.

Also, Occam's Razor may argue for the Many Worlds interpretation, rather than against it.

The problem is that you are hearing the abridged, "Reader's Digest" version of the Many Worlds interpretation and assuming that that's the whole story.

As far as I understand, a more accurate version is that when something ("an observer") interacts with something in a superposition of states, this "observer" enters a similar superposition of states. Not really.

First of all, you are assuming that travel between these parallel universes is actually possible, which may not be the case. If such travel is impossible, then there would be no universe where they discovered how to do it.

Second, there is an element of probability in Quantum Mechanics that is missing from most *explanations* of the Many Worlds interpretation. Even if some universes discover inter-universal travel, they may be "rare," with similarly rare destinations.

Incorrect. Bell's inequality shows that, if there "hidden variables" that determined the outcome of quantum events in advance, certain patters would emerge over repeated experiments. Quantum Mechanics predicts a different pattern, and the Quantum Mechanical pattern is the one actually observed.
You sound just like Niko form Corridor Digital.

The theory, stated somewhat more properly, is that every possible outcome of a Quantum event/measurement actually occurs - more simply, if something is possible, it happens. If the Many Worlds interpretation is the correct interpretation of Quantum Mechanics, then it being the incorrect interpretation is not a possible outcome, so would be no alternative universe where the Many Worlds interpretation is incorrect.

Look up Bell's inequality. The Cliff's notes version is that Bell's inequality shows that if there really were only one deterministic universe, we could expect certain patterns to emerge over repeated experiments. Quantum Mechanics predicts a different pattern and Quantum Mechanical pattern is the one observed in the real world.

Also, your premise ("We see objects in only one state each") does not lead to your conclusion ("The objects must be in only one state each").

Regarding the double slit experiment and it's relation to quantum states:

- Light is often modeled as a wave function which can overlap with one another (just as in any other wave models like sound which, if overlapped, can result in superposition and thus an increased intensity.
- But on the double slit experiment the interference pattern produced by the monochromatic light suggests otherwise, that light can be a particle model rather than a wave model which cancels one another out.

This is called the "measurement problem". According to the classical interpretation of Quantum Physics, the superposition of states in a physical system (eg, both alive and dead) propagates and persists until it is observed by a sentient being, wich "chooses" what it sees or experiment. That's why you must open the box and look inside, or else, any possible state of that system will not "collapse" into a single state as we are used to observe until this happens (to look inside).

The beauty of Bell's inequality is that it works regardless of gaps in our knowledge and our inability to create two identical experiments.

The whole point of Bell Inequality is that if each experiment has only one possible outcome, patterns will emerge over many experiments, even if the experiments are not completely identical and even if we cannot determine what the one possible outcome of each one is.

The Schrodinger's cat experiment is more of a metaphor to explain how weird quantum mechanical phenomena are. E.g., under our classical intuition, a top can spin either counterclockwise ("up") or clockwise ("down"). Subatomic particles, and even atoms, can have both "up" and "down" spin at the same time.

The idea of a cat being both alive and dead at the same time is meant as a metaphor to illustrate just how weird this is.

No, you see, that's what uncertainty is. It's mathematically proven that the world of quantum mechanics is fuzzy and uncertain, and there is a lower boundary of the minimum uncertainty on a quantity, assuming you have knowledge of another observable that doesn't commute with the first one. Examples are momentum and position, or energy and time. You don't get to know how fast you're going AND where you are, and no measuring device can ever tell you.

Also no, laws are usually part of theories. There is no 'law of gravity' but we do have a 'theory of gravity'. Although as far as I'm concerned it's very incomplete. But then again that's why science is awesome. A theory or 'law' isn't a dogma, as long as you get new data, you can build up on it.

Theories cannot become laws. Physical laws like the laws of gravity describe a phenomenon which occurs over and over without fail, whereas theories are proposed and experimentally tested ideas of why those phenomena occur, in simple terms. They are fundamentally different things.

It's a lethal aount, but it's triggered by a radioactive decay. If a geiger counter registers 1 count of the radioactive material decaying, the cat dies. At any given time, there is a chance that this has happened, and thus the same chance that the cat is dead. Similarly, 1-(that chance) = the chance that the cat is alive. You can't ppredict when something 'll decay, it's a completely random process. Thus at any point in time, the cat is in a superposition of alive and dead to an outsider.
